title: French marathon runner named Marie saves children drowning in Cornwallis near Auckland, New Zealand
text:
A mystery French marathon runner saved two young children from drowning after they were swept out to sea by a strong current.

A girl aged six and a boy aged eight had got into difficulty after jumping off a wharf in Cornwallis near Auckland, New Zealand at the weekend.

Witnesses said the boy was in shock and the girl was vomiting seawater as they struggled to stay afloat while the current dragged them out.

A mystery French marathon runner (pictured) saved two young children from drowning after they were swept out to sea by a strong current

A girl aged six and a boy aged eight had got into difficulty after jumping off a wharf (pictured) in Cornwallis near Auckland, New Zealand at the weekend

The brave woman, who told locals her name was Marie, jumped in after them.

She held them afloat for 10 minutes until people in a dingy paddled over and fished them out of the water about 200m from land.

The local who rowed the dingy told the New Zealand Herald: 'When I got to the girl [the French athlete], she said, 'I've got no strength left'.

'She was holding up the two children and trying to swim at the same time,' the resident said.

'She was a very, very courageous girl. She could have drowned herself.'

The brave woman (right in black after the rescue) who told locals her name was Marie, jumped in after the children

Residents said the woman was a firefighter who was in New Zealand to run the Auckland marathon on October 20 - but she only gave her name as Marie.

The children were taken in an ambulance to Starship Hospital with suspected hypothermia.

A spokeswoman for the hospital said: 'We received two patients in relation to this incident. One has been discharged and the other is stable.'
description: A girl aged six and a boy aged eight had got into difficulty after jumping off a wharf in Cornwallis near Auckland, New Zealand at the weekend.
authors: Charlie Moore For Daily Mail Australia
